unnormalised: ## Basket Case: Why Your Online Shopping Cart Feels Like a Breakup Scene from a Karan Johar Film
normalised: Basket Case: Why Your Online Shopping Cart Feels Like a Breakup Scene from a Karan Johar Film

unnormalised: So, you’ve spent a delightful 20 minutes browsing through the latest saree collection on Myntra. You’ve envisioned yourself rocking that Kanjeevaram at your cousin Priya’s wedding in Delhi. You’ve mentally calculated how many samosas you can buy with the money you *save* by getting it on sale. You click "Add to Cart," feeling a surge of retail therapy joy.
normalised: So, you’ve spent a delightful twenty minutes browsing through the latest saree collection on Myntra. You click "Add to Cart," feeling a surge of retail therapy joy.

unnormalised: The cart sits there, a lonely, abandoned testament to your almost-purchase. You close the browser. Dinner needs making. Amitabh Bachchan is on TV. That Kanjeevaram? Well, maybe later.
normalised: The cart sits there, a lonely, abandoned testament to your almost-purchase. You close the browser. Dinner needs making. Amitabh Bachchan is on T V. That Kanjeevaram? Well, maybe later.

unnormalised: Sound familiar? You, my friend, are a cart abandoner!
normalised: Sound familiar? You, my friend, are a cart abandoner!

unnormalised: And you're not alone. In the e-commerce world, cart abandonment is the *original* "It's not you, it's me" breakup. It's more common than finding a functioning ATM on a Sunday. Studies estimate that nearly 70% of online shopping carts end up abandoned, like a jilted lover left at the altar in a Bollywood film. Talk about a drama!

unnormalised: Why does this happen? Well, picture this: you're excited about a new gadget, but then you see the shipping charges. Rs. 250? Really? Suddenly, that gadget seems a lot less appealing. It's like finding out your dream job at IIM Bangalore pays peanuts.
normalised: Why does this happen? Well, picture this: you're excited about a new gadget, but then you see the shipping charges. Rupee two hundred and fifty? Really? Suddenly, that gadget seems a lot less appealing. It's like finding out your dream job at I I M Bangalore pays peanuts.

unnormalised: Or maybe you got distracted. A WhatsApp forward from your family group about the latest miracle cure? A sudden craving for pani puri? Life happens!
normalised: Or maybe you got distracted. A WhatsApp forward from your family group about the latest miracle cure? A sudden craving for pani puri? Life happens!

unnormalised: So, retailers, take note! High shipping costs, complicated checkout processes, and requiring account creation are the villains of this story. They’re like the annoying relatives who always comment on your weight at family gatherings.
normalised: So, retailers, take note! High shipping costs, complicated checkout processes, and requiring account creation are the villains of this story. They’re like the annoying relatives who always comment on your weight at family gatherings.

unnormalised: The good news? Cart abandonment isn't a death sentence. With a little effort (and maybe a well-timed email with a discount code), those abandoned items can find their way back into customers' hearts (and shopping bags). After all, even Rahul and Anjali needed a second chance, didn't they?
